abstracts.cdata!:
The Casamance Emergency Reconstruction
            Support Project aims to support the Government of Senegal
            in: (a) facilitating a speedy restoration in Casamance of a
            productive economic and social environment similar to that
            existing in the rest of Senegal; and (b) laying the
            groundwork for sustainable long-term development in the
            region, while fully respecting its specificities. To achieve
            its objectives, the project will have three components: (1)
            demobilization and reinsertion of combatants and other
            conflict victims; (2) infrastructure reconstruction and
            rehabilitation; and (3) technical support for the
            preparation o f a long-term development program. In
            addition, the National Agency for the Recovery o f Social
            and Economic Activities in Casamance (ANRAC) will directly
            implement other cross-cutting activities, such as
            instituting a management information system. The project
            will benefit Senegal as a whole and the Casamance region in
            particular. All ex-combatants and their families will be
            offered opportunities to resume normal civilian lives with
            appropriate economic activities. Approximately 30,000
            displaced persons will be supported in their return to
            normal life in their original homes. After project
            completion, Casamance is expected to be an exporter of
            agricultural products abroad and a supplier to the local
            Senegalese market. Significant foreign direct investment in
            the tourism sector should also occur once regional stability
            is secured. External risks to the project include: 1. A
            full-scale rebellion because of disagreements between the
            Rebellion Movement in Casamance (MFDC) and the Government;
            and repeated attacks staged by gangs of former combatants.
            Project risks comprise the following: 1) Poor coordination
            among the various efforts taking place in Casamance; 2) Lack
            of collaboration/trust between the administration and the
            beneficiaries.; 3) Slowness of implementation and
            disbursement; and 4) Inability of displaced persons to
            return to their original homes.
